item.title: Don’t Be Confused. Real Success is Exhausting.
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Real success is exhausting, because nothing good comes easy. Or to quote the late Dr. Scott Peck, “love is work, non-love is laziness, and anti-love is evil.”

Evil exists, but it is very rare. Most people are just lazy. Financially lazy, emotionally lazy, intellectually lazy, philosophically lazy — even work lazy. Most people, just don’t want to do the work that sustainable success requires.

Personally, 2015 was an exhausting year for me. My most exhausting yet, actually. And I really have no problem with this. Like I said, nothing good comes easy.

Malcolm Gladwell’s book “The Outliers” note than it takes 10,000 hours to become a master, or a best-in-class leader at whatever your chosen profession or passion might be. This boils down to about 20 hours a week, or a very real part time job.

And to be clear, this means 20 hours a week, on top of normal full-time job commitment. Whatever you want to achieve will take commitment, it will take hours, and it will be at times, exhausting.

If you want to be successful, or if you are presently experiencing what I would call ‘real success,’ then you can expect moments and stretches of exhaustion. But this is not to be confused with being ‘tired,’ because when you are tired, you actually don’t like what you are doing.

When you do what you are passionate about, you don’t get tired. You get worn out. You may be exhausted. But you actually love what you do, which is why you keep doing it — maybe to a point of ‘exhaustion.'

Life really is a math equation, on many levels. If you want true success, you are simply going to have to put in some serious hours. Success in anything.

If you want success in professional sports, you will have to put in serious hours of practice and preparation, not just actual play.

If you want to be a top attorney, you will have to do much more than finish law school. You will have to put in serious hours, to sit at the knee of noted legal experts, to study case law, to understand history and context, and remain connecting to all that is going on today. And of course, to run a successful practice too.

If you want to be a successful entrepreneur, you will have to invest serious hours, and to understand my entrepreneurship creed. “An entrepreneur works 18 hours a day, just to keep from getting a real job.”

But this is not just limited to the professions.

If you want to be a great parent, because maybe your mother or father wasn’t to you growing up — then you will have to put in serious hours at home, with them. There is no way around it.

When I see a successful leader who also happens to also be married, and I note that he or she enjoys a healthy relationship with their children, or just healthy children, I always try to commend the partner in that marriage as a similarly successful 'Domestic Engineer.’

Running that household, and raising those children, and filling that home with love, took everything that the wife (in this particular, more traditional example) had, just like professional success required of the other here.

In 2015, I had to battle a 'library of professional headwinds' that required almost everything I had.

Transformation of an organization from an old business model, into a new one.

Getting rid of what my friends at Gallup would call ‘highly disengaged’ workers.

Or workers who show up actively rooting for your failure. You are literally paying these people to undermine your vision; for yourself and your organization. They simply have to go. You will find a few of them even in the best of organizations.

Bringing in new talent and leadership, and doing it without sending some sort of a message to your current team that they ~ their jobs, their positions ~ are somehow also now ‘at risk.'

Bringing stakeholders along -- board members, partners, vendors, supporters, constituents, clients and customers along with you throughout all of this change.

Hitting my numbers and solving very hairy problems, in the midst of all of these other challenges and changes.

Taking in order for more than 280 new Operation HOPE locations dedicated to Project 5117, led by HOPE Inside and HOPE Business In A Box Academies.

I also had to find more than 3M in new cash revenue early in 2015 — literally out of no where. And I had to do this, while also keeping all of my other commitments.

Managing a local, mostly annoying challenge of being actively undermined by a former staffer. It did not work, and it did not last for long, but in the moment it was time consuming. And time is what I actually value most.

“If you ask me if I wanted more time, or more money, I would ask for more time. If I had more time, I could then make more money."

When you are top business leader, a government leader, a cutting edge innovation leader, or a market leader, or a sector leader, community leader, religious leader, moral leader or an industry leader, or any other kind of best-in-class leader ~ know and understand that it will take almost everything that you have to continue to win. To achieve sustainable success.

And so you ask, was it all worth it? Absolutely.

2015 was my most exhausting year yet, but it was also my most fulfilling.

We got the most done, expanded the mission in ways not seen in the previous 23 plus years, and transformed the baseline of the organization — from the inside out. All of this, while keeping the financials strong, and the organization firmly rooted in 'good governance.'

We were able to inspire the U.S. Secretary of the Treasury to rename a 100+ year old building, previously known as the U.S. Treasury Annex Building, to the Freedman’s Bank Building, in honor of President Lincoln’s mandate to create a bank after the civil war to ‘teach freed slaves about money.’ We see our HOPE Inside network as a natural extension of the Freedman’s Bank mission and mandate, and we opened more than three dozen HOPE Inside locations across the country in 2015.

And finally, we set up the environment for the hosting of our biggest and best HOPE Global Forum Annual Meeting for Operation HOPE (the organization I founded nearly 25 years ago after the Rodney King Riots in South Central Los Angeles, in 1992), scheduled for this coming week, January 13-15, 2016, here in Atlanta.

So, was it worth it? No doubt. Did it take everything I had, a little more that my family and team had — absolutely yes. But this, is what success looks like.

Love is work. Loss creates leaders, and rainbows only follow storms. You cannot have a rainbow, without a storm first.

I am a better person, and I believe a stronger and more clear headed leader after the hard work of 2015. I would not change a thing. My word for 2016 is to Execute. What's yours?

Commit to your dreams, and don’t complain when occasionally those dreams make you want to scream. Nothing good, comes easy.

I like what Dr. Dorothy I. Height had to say about me. “I like you John, because you are a dreamer, with a shovel in your hands."

Let us now be dreamers, with shovels in our hands.

Let’s go.

 

By John Hope Bryant

Article source: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/dont-confused-real-success-exhausting-john-hope-bryant

item.title: How to Get Candidates to Like You and Respond to Your Emails
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Recruiter’s block: Noun, phrase. The condition of being unable to think of how to recruit people or how to proceed with recruiting.

No matter how long you’ve been in the space, you may have already hit the dreaded recruiting wall. A waning talent funnel. Snubbed emails. Dead open and response rates. Getting lost in the shuffle of competing companies is a common hiring nightmare.

Then comes flattery – express appeal, leverage, then negotiate. Try these three moves to stand out from the long list of contenders.
Ask about something they worked on.
This isn’t the run-of-the-mill recruiter template that, at the least, name-drops a press piece, blog post, or project. Take the M.O. of starting a conversation with someone you’re a fan of, over email. Use your subject line to specifically compliment what they’re associated with, like, a company achievement or something they’ve created. In the message, offer your response on the topic and ask a question.

Here’s an example:

Subject line: Fantastic post about clever ways to recruit talent!

Hey Kathleen,

I just read your post with new ideas on attracting and engaging candidates. (Link) Interesting take! Our team’s always talked about doing candidate surveys, and I think this post was just the kicker for us to finally get started.

Question: What are your thoughts on texting candidates? I’m all for it, but the rest of my team thinks it’s an aggressive approach. What say you?

Hope your day is going well so far. Looking forward to hearing from you. Cheers!

Seeking insights from a candidate lets them know you value their opinion, and they’ll offer their two cents in return – the icebreaker to (tastefully) turning on recruit mode.

Requesting to use their work.
Similar to the previous point, asking for permission to use something a candidate’s created is another way to let them know you’re paying attention to their repertoire. Stumble upon an idea you admire and want to share, and use that as fuel to open up your conversation.

Survey candidates.
Here’s how to learn more about the people you’re recruiting, and to warm up to you recruiting them. You’ve probably been told to start being data-driven and if you don’t know where to start, try ramping up by studying the people you’re trying to hire.

One approach that recently caught my attention was a company reaching out to candidates over a 15 minute phone call for feedback on what they love most about their job. The trade-off was a $50 gift card for their time. Done tactfully, to start, you’ll attract people willing to wax lyrical about their role. “Talk to someone about themselves, and they’ll listen for hours.”

Fuel questions to get them to open up about what makes them excited about their role or the space they work in. Here are some questions to start: What got you interested in the space you’re in now? What do you love most about your work? What are some aspects that make up a good, strong company culture? What are some benefits and perks a company could offer that would make them stand out from others?

You’ll get a better understanding of the candidate market and how to make your opportunities stand out from the shuffle other companies vying for the same people. Even if you meet someone unhappy with their job but who can articulate what they are looking for, you’d land a prime chance to transition into talking about what your company can offer.

In one word, this post is about personalization. Like meeting someone for the first time, getting a candidate to warm up to you requires a gradual, calculated approach, and some research. If you want more tips on building out candidate emails, check out most popular eBook, Effectively Messaging Candidates.

Source:

November 12, 2015 at 1:00 PM Kathleen de Lara

item.title: 5 Habits Every Recruiter Needs for Killer Results
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
“All our life is a mass of habits,” wrote philosopher William James. Habits, both good and bad, play a powerful role in our lives. Consider your habits at the office? Coffee, Facebook, check email, read the news, grab a snack. Which actively contribute to your success or inhibit it? Now, wipe the slate clean, because we’ve got five daily habits to drive your productivity and keep you recruiting like a rockstar.

Make a to-do list every day
What are you doing today? Do you know? Think about what reqs need to be written or approved. Do you need to finalize an offer or lock in a phone screen? Making a list of all the things you need to do, both big and small, allows you to map out your entire day and strategically hold yourself accountable. The present wealth of productivity apps make tracking stuff easier than ever.

Our favorites? We love Asana at Entelo because it’s useful for monitor and organizing projects and tasks between teams. But there’s also Todoist, Evernote, or even Remember The Milk. Once you’ve got a list, sync up with your team to see what can be delegated or shared. Also, periodically check in with hiring managers to help move candidates along in the hiring process. If you know what needs to be done, the odds of accomplishing those tasks will skyrocket. And that’s the first step towards killer results.

Check the pipes
Your pipeline is your lifeline, so make sure it’s operating at peak capacity and efficiency. How? Check on it daily to figure out what aspects are underperforming. Knowing the ins and outs of your pipeline is fundamental to all recruiting results and can drive actionable improvements. Lagging on referrals? Then send out a company-wide email with available positions and reiterate the referral bonus. Better yet, consider setting aside time to meet with employees to browse through their networks to find out who’d be qualified candidates.

Always ask yourself: What’s working? What’s not working? How can we improve? A strong pipeline keeps everything else running smoothly by making your hiring process quicker, more exact, and minimizes the disruption from unexpected vacancies to your company’s bottom line.

Prioritize relentlessly
Once your to-do list is written, prioritize tasks in descending order of the most pressing and time sensitive. Know your Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), both those set for you and those you set for yourself. One great way to keep yourself focused: the 1-3-5 rule. This framework divides your daily to-dos into one important task, three medium tasks, and five small tasks. Align your to-do list with the 1-3-5 rule based on your KPIs and budget your time and efforts appropriately. If you always get your most important task done each day, accomplish most of the medium tasks and some of the small tasks, you’ll be in great shape. And if you haven’t figured out KPIs yet, here is a good place to start.

Geek out with metrics
Data is cool. You know what’s even cooler? Metrics. Metrics like total candidate pipeline, response rates for each sourcing channel and time to hire allow you to identify, isolate and fix problems, inefficiencies, and roadblocks. ATSs like Greenhouse and Lever now make it fairly straightforward to track candidates and outcomes, so there’s really no excuse.

The difference between a good recruiter and a great recruiter is that great recruiters are always working to get better; constant data-driven iteration is a foolproof way to improve your game. Always check to see what channels and actions give you the best ROI and which are lagging. Identifying what works best and what needs improvement will help you hone in on efficiencies and inefficiencies, making you a smarter, more effective recruiter.

Always be syncing
Never underestimate the value of teamwork in recruiting. Whether it’s your colleagues, managers, subordinates, or peers at another company altogether, sharing intel, asking questions and working together to tackle complex problems is the quickest way out of dead-ends. It also builds the kind of team-first ethic that is crucial in recruiting, especially since personal referrals are still the best way to find talented hires. It’s tempting for hunter-type recruiters to attack things solo, but the most successful companies and best departments are created by constant teamwork. Set up various daily and weekly touch points for your team, to make sure everyone is on the same page with hiring strategies, responsibilities, and priorities.

One tactic we’ve implemented at Entelo is setting aside 10 minutes for a quick post-interview candidate debrief. Did they meet expectations? Were they only qualified on paper or did they completely bomb the interview? Learning how to continually align recruiter-hiring manager expectations for candidates helps teams be more efficient selecting candidates and only moving forward with the best ones.

Daily habits are a powerful way to achieve amazing results and keep yourself goal-oriented. The key is to eliminate bad habits and create good ones. Let us know in the comments what your unique recruiting habits are.

Keep recruiting like an all-star – we rallied Kenny Mendes, of Box's founding recruiting team, to show you how.

January 28, 2016 at 12:16 PM William Clarke

item.title: 10 Things Not to Do in Your Pitch Emails
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Pitch emails are your first touch point with candidates and ideally they begin a long, fruitful conversation that’s mutually productive.

The stronger the pitch, the more responses you will get, and the bigger your pipeline will grow. As we’ve said before, your pipeline is your lifeline. Here’s a guide on what not to say and do in your candidate emails so that you can recruit like a pro, and hire like a boss.

Let’s start with a few things candidates will see first.
Unclear Subject Line
Short, punchy, and straightforward are rules to live by here. NO ALL CAPS, ever. In general, you’re aiming for a subject line that is specific, brief, conversational and doesn’t feel too serious. You want to engage them without being pushy, vague or obnoxious.

Here are three styles I like:

Personalized and warm: Jack, loved your medium post on Series B rounds
Open-ended: Quick question when you have a moment
Direct, no-nonsense: Sales Opportunity with Fast Growing SaaS Startup
Thought-provoking question: Patrick, What’s Next?
If you’re doing research into your candidates, you should be able to get an idea of what they’re like. Pick a direction you think fits their personality and background. Some may go for the direct, straightforward message that gives them an overview before they have even clicked the message. Others may respond to a softer touch that begins as a conversation about something else before transitioning to their job prospects.

Bad Timing
In hiring, timing is everything. What do we mean? Well, most candidates switch jobs around their first, second or third work anniversaries, which makes two to four months before that anniversary the best time for you to message them.

Now let’s move on to your email message.
Make Demands
Remember, someone you’re sending a cold email to owes you absolutely nothing. While you may want to offer them a job eventually, your goal right now is to begin a conversation. You are already occupying their time, so always use a light touch. Make sure to convey that you respect their time and have zero expectations. That way you are deferring to them and their availability.

Being generic
It doesn’t take a genius to figure out when you have just received a mass email, so don’t be that recruiter. Instead, personalize every message. Call out something cool they worked on or led, like a GitHub fork, a blog post, a Tweetstorm, or a particular marketing campaign.

See a someone you know connected to them on their professional profile? Use the opportunity to namedrop your mutual connection.

Typos or bad grammar
The mistake of death. Misspelling a job candidate's name makes you look careless. Using poor grammar makes you look careless. A 2015 Hubspot study reported bad grammar as people’s number one pet peeve. If you’re not a stellar writer, Grammarly is a great way to double check your writing and even learn rules.

Burying the Lede
Don’t write a novel. Get to the point, explain why you are reaching out, why you’re touching base with them specifically, and propose any next steps. Two or three brief paragraphs at most should do it. If your message can’t be read in less than a minute, it’s too long.

Sounding like a Robot
You don’t want your email to sound like Siri wrote it. Use real human language and put some personality into it (but not too much). “Hey Bob, Hope you’re well. I don’t know whether or not you’re looking to change companies, but if so, I think you would be a great fit for an Enterprise Sales role here at Entelo.”

Before sending your message, read it out loud. If you wouldn’t say it verbally, don’t write it.

Misrepresent Yourself, Your Company or the Position
Don’t fudge details on salary, job title, or expectations. If you wind up losing a candidate because what you told them something that was not true, you’ve burned a bridge, made your company (and yourself) look untrustworthy, and wasted the time of anyone else who participated in phone screens or interviews.

Honesty is the best policy. Always. If your company can’t match their salary expectations or the candidate doesn’t want to make a lateral move, so be it. Your employer brand is sacrosanct.

BCC Multiple Candidates
Emailing multiple people at once puts you in the fast track to get embarrassed. We’ve heard multiple stories about people who received a pitch at the same exact time as a co-worker. Neither of those people are going to respond to you, so just don’t do it.

Leaving out an action item
Make sure they know what you’re looking for. Say, “I would love to hear your thoughts on the declining tech valuations and how you think that might impact hiring,” or “Do you think you’d be interested in hearing more about our company?” or “Let me know if you have any interest in hearing about new opportunities.”

Even better, send them a link to your careers page or a company culture video to revisit if they want a primer before responding to your email.

Not thanking them
People are busy and they receive a lot of emails. If they bothered to read your entire message, be sure to end on a positive note. Thanking them shows them you appreciate their time and ends on a note that could just be enough to get them to respond.

If you follow all of these tips, you’ll be in good shape. Think we missed something? Share it in the comments, and be sure to check out our most popular eBook on the fundamentals of candidate outreach!

 

March 3, 2016 at 12:22 PM William Clarke

item.title: Congratulations to...
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Regina Gatti, for making $75 extra cash for 2 internal referrals that led to interviews in our NY office….one of these hires could make her $1,000

Lauren Fliehman for making $50 for a referral that led to an interview in our Chicago office

Lisa Figuccio who stands to make $2,500 for a hire we just made on one of her referrals

 

Don’t forget we are still offering $25/$50 Amex cards for general referrals and  we are still offering a $250 cash prize if anyone refers us an experienced SALES Temp Manager (with strong billing) or EXPERIENCED PERM RECRUITER(with strong billing).

But I also wanted to stress that we are looking for an experienced internal recruiter to support ME and this $250 relates to this as well (if Matt or I prescreen them and we follow up with the meeting.)

Please keep this in mind throughout your work day efforts and thereafter! And our INTERNAL referral policy - http://bit.ly/gkr_referrals

 

PS - Quick job description if u need to send to someone for the internal recruiting role:

  • Recruit temporary/permanent recruiters/sales folks by cold calling, reviewing resumes and assessing candidates’ applications.
  • Utilizing both standard and creative sourcing strategies to identify top talent and find qualified candidates in new markets and existing industry verticals
  • Network, build and maintain relationships with industry professionals and organizations
  • Maintain network of candidates by using company’s applicant tracking system
  • Participate in branding, marketing and implementing new social media strategies
  • Strong base plus bonus and/or commission –
  • Must be very comfortable on the phones and have a strong sales ability and persistent personality
  • Location in NYC
  • Ideally someone with 3-8 years of either contract recruitment or any cold calling, recruiting experience within a Sales style company.

 

Think of your own networks – family/friends(social networks) and of course your business contacts!

item.title: Inc. 5000 Fast Growing List
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Green Key Resources, has been named to the prestigious Inc. 5000 list of the nation’s fastest growing private companies. Inc. magazine ranked Green Key for its triple digit growth rate on the widely regarded list, where such firms as Dell, Pandora and LinkedIn gained early national exposure.

“We’re excited to be named to the Inc. 5000 list,” said Andrew Chayut, Managing Partner of Green Key Resources. “Growing 140% in three years could only be accomplished by the efforts of our recruiters and everyone on our internal support teams who work hard to build relationships with our clients.

“Day in and day out our resourcing teams provide our clients highly talented, quality professionals to fill some of the toughest jobs and handle the most challenging temporary assignments.

“Our placement on the list is a tribute to their efforts. Our growth over the last few years demonstrates the confidence our clients have in us,” Chayut added.

Green Key Resources’ 175 employees across six offices place candidates nationally in the demanding fields of accounting and finance, financial services, healthcare and pharmaceutical, information technology, office support, HR, and legal support. The company’s recruitment team fills short and long term temporary/contract assignments as well as direct-hire placements across all specialty areas.

Besides earning a place on the Inc. 5000 list, Green Key Resources was named the top executive recruiting firm in New York City by Crain’s New York Business in 2014.

Visit us here for more information or call us at 212.683.1988.

item.title: Green Key Runs NYC!

item.title: Please help me welcome Elissa, a new member of our AF team
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded: Elissa Friedland – Accounting/Finance, NY – x295 I graduated from the University of Delaware in 2009 with a B.S. in accounting. I started my career at Ernst and Young in the financial services office.  After three years at EY, I moved over to fund accounting at Davidson Kempner.  After coming to the realization that accounting is not my passion, I decided recruiting would be a great  fit for me since I have a strong interest in working with people and understand the financial services industry from my past experience.   My interests include tennis and traveling.  I am extremely excited to join the Green Key team and look forward to meeting everyone.

item.title: Orlando Office Ups Ante In Fundraising Runs
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded: Giving back has always been important to us at Green Key. You might remember that last summer 70 of our team members from our New York and Long Island offices joined up for a fundraising run through Central Park. And at the end of September a dozen other team members took part in a walk-a-thon raising funds to help cancer research facilities buy shipment. Not to be outdone, our Orlando office has been upping the ante, participating in their second fundraising run in just two months. Three days after the Boston marathon tragedy, seven of our team members took part in a half-marathon fundraiser through Orlando’s downtown. To show their solidarity with the runners and citizens of Boston, all 16,400 participants in the Orlando run sang “Sweet Caroline” and put a hand over their heart as they crossed the finished line. On the Green Key team were: Larry Goodman, executive director pharmaceutical, Mike Baio, executive director IT, and his 16-year-old son Nicholas, Krista Nehring, recruiting manager pharmaceutical, Joey Mastropietro, business development manager, Michael Geddie, associate recruiter, Jennifer Alexandrowicz, senior recruiter, Lauren Scutero, associate recruiter,  and Mary Painter, director of temporary pharmaceutical. A portion of the funds raised are being contributed to the Boston victims. - See more at: http://www.greenkeyllc.com/blog/category/working-at-green-key/#sthash.GPuRleTT.dpuf

item.title: Steve Gold promoted to Partner
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
We’d like to extend our congratulations to Steve Gold on his promotion to Partner today !!!
Steve has been a part of the “fiber” of this firm since early 2007.
 
He’s been a tremendous asset to not only Green Key’s financial services “direct hire” team BUT to Green Key overall.

item.title: We have welcomed 3 new employees in the last week...
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded: Rob Bertino - Florida, IT, x384 I bring over 7 years of recruiting experience with a core focus on IT. I moved to Florida in 1996 to attend Full Sail University, a recording arts school in Orlando. I earned two specialized Associate of Science degrees: Audio Engineering and Digital Media. A few years later I decided to go back to school to obtain a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Management from the University of Phoenix. On my free time I enjoy cooking, swimming, entertaining with friends, graphic design, watching football, hockey, boxing and spending quality time with my wife Kristen and two young boys Blake and Dominic. I am excited to be part of GKR and have a chance to meet many of you in the future. Melanie Mednick - Long Island Temp, Staffing, x407 I graduated from Emerson College in Boston after transferring out of Berklee College of Music. I am so excited to start my career at Green Key Resources. I love to sing and write songs, as well as, do musical theatre. I look forward for meeting everyone! CJ Tufano – Long Island - Accounting/Finance, x408 I graduated from Hofstra University in 2009 after 3 years with a Bachelor’s Degree in Accounting. I also played Club Baseball there and still play to this day. I started my accounting career with Grant Thornton in 2009 working on mostly commercial audit clients while also gaining plenty of experience working on 30 different clients ranging from broker dealers to supermarkets. After working at GT for 18 months, I started working at Cablevision as a Senior Accountant. I was introduced to recruiting by Billy Fine and Jay Kondrup. I was intrigued by the opportunity and was originally considering joining Green Key back in 2011.  Needless to say, two years later I am back to pursue the opportunity that I should of taken all along.  I look forward to meeting and working with everyone here!

Jackie DeJohn - Financial Services, NYC - x171
I graduated from Fairfield University in 2009. I studied communications and politics and dove on the swim team. I started my career as a recruiter at Northwestern Mutual Financial Network. I worked for the Mergis Group, a Randstad company for 3 months, before joining the team at GKR. I enjoy skiing, spending time with my friends and family, and walking my dog, Zeus. I look forward to meeting and working with everyone at GKR.

item.title: Welcome to our newest member of IT- Daniel Thompson
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded: Daniel Thompson -IT Recruiter, NYC- x120 I graduated from the University of Massachusetts – Amherst where I played on the club soccer team.  I started my recruiting career at a boutique staffing agency that specialized in Information Technology, and recently concluded a 2 year stint at The Execu Search Group where I served as our teams Lead IT Recruiter.  In my free time I really enjoy traveling to music festivals, and going on long road trips.  I recently returned from a long weekend trip to Chicago, and am looking forward to a trip to Denver for the Christmas holiday.  I am very grateful and excited about the opportunity of working at GKR, and look forward to meeting everyone!

item.title: I Want YOU on Green Key's Movember Team!!!!
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Attention Green Key (all offices)!!! In Movember, I'll be growing a moustache AKA “Mo” to raise funds and awareness for men's health. 
I want YOU to be part of it. This is a great way to spark conversations about important health issues, and maybe grab a candidate or client in the process!!! Female employees can join the team too and help raise funds for the team!  It’s the same process without the Mo!    
 
What’s Next? Click on this link -  http://moteam.co/green-key - and JOIN the team!!  
You can customize your personal page and there are templates available to help you ask for donations starting Nov 1st .   
 
There will be a Happy Hour / Kickoff Party on Friday, November 1st  at 5:30pm.  
Bar near Green Key NYC office. 
Details to follow.   
        
Gentlemen - if you are joining the team, please come to work with a clean shaven face on November 1st.  You have one month to grow your Mo and raise money for our team.   
RULES AND STYLEGUIDE ARE ATTACHED! Our Goal To raise $10,000 for men’s health (prostate and testicular cancer, and mental health).   If we have 40 members on the team, we would need to raise $250.00 each in one month.   An ambitious goal, but you must believe in the power of the Mo!   All donations are tax deductable.  Thanks for supporting the Green Key Movember Team and helping us change the face of men's health. Email me directly with questions! Unlock  your Mo!
 
Read more in the following attachments: 
MO13 Download Rules  Letter I FA PDF
MO13_Download_Styleguide_I_FA_PDF 
 
Anthony Puleo Director, Green Key Temp
Direct: 212-584-6416 
Mobile: 917-750-7174
Email: anthony@greenkeyllc.com

Welcome to our newest member - Ariel Whittingham (read more below)
Ariel Whittingham -  Research Analyst, NYC- x133
I attended Colgate University where I pursued a degree in philosophy and a minor in economics. After graduating, and realizing that Philosophy majors are quite uncompetitive in the job market, I spent my summer traveling and unsuccessfully applying to for jobs in New York City. Nonetheless, I found Green Key about a month ago, and after speaking with your own Michelle Nelson (in the pharmaceutical division) I decided to to go forward with the interview process and eventually take the offer. I don't have any related sales or recruiting experience, but I am excited to learn the industry. I hope that over the next few weeks I have a chance to meet and get to know all of you.

item.title: Its Holiday Time!! Gifts and E-Cards being sent on your behalf
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Client Brownie Baskets
On Monday the holiday baskets will be going out to your client contacts. We will be sending 24 brownie bites in a GKR branded box (If you have been in my office you have seen the box).
Please make sure to follow up with your clients you added to my list at the end of the week to make sure they arrived (they should all arrive by Thursday 12/12)

 E-Holiday Cards
We will be sending a cool looking /animated e-card at the end of next week/beginning of the week after, to the databases. It will be sent on your behalf to all of our inactive/active/placed candidates and clients with a donation to 2 charities on their behalf. We will be donating to:           
 
- The New York Organ Donor Network (which recovers organs and tissues for people in need of life-saving and life-improving transplants). This donation is made in memory of Jeffrey Whitehead, James’s younger brother.     
        
- The American Heart Association (committed to building healthier lives free of cardiovascular diseases and stroke). This donation is made in memory of David Bleichfeld, my husband.

item.title: Welcome the newest members of the team!
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Alice Ping

Born and raised in New York City, I attended Hunter College and majored in Geography. Really believed I was going to go into city planning but didn’t really develop a passion for it. I worked 5 years at a privately owned small business consisting of five boutiques as a Personal Shopper and the company buyer. I left the B2C realm and became the Office Manager/Executive Assistant at a start-up company. A year into working with the company I was promoted to Human Resource Associate where I owned the full life-cycle of a candidate and new hire. I’m very excited to come into a role that combines my previous Sales and HR experience. On my free time I enjoy  activities outside of NY such as hiking and kayaking.

Ethan Sencer

item.title: Resume writing tips from our very own Steve Gold and Matt Carbon, read more on Business Insider
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Resist the urge to list your last position as "present."

You should always be honest if you are no longer working at a company. If you have to explain yourself later, it may seem to hiring managers that you misled them.
Instead, Steven A. Gold and Matthew Carbon, recruiters at executive recruitment firm Green Key Resources, say you should include the reason for the gap in brackets next to the date of employment on your résumé. For example, you can put "Position was automated," "Department eliminated," or "Position downsized" in brackets if you've been laid off.
But you should only do this for the most recent position you've held, they say. You don't want to have a bracket next to every job position on your resume.
If you've been terminated, remember that employers understand that the employment market and business environment is challenging for employees. Having a layoff or a job with a short tenure won't completely eliminate you, but having a series of short tenures may raise red flags, says McDonald.


Read more: http://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-address-layoff-on-resume-2013-12#ixzz2nHAMo3Ps

item.title: News Item from Orlando
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Mike Baio's son Nicholas participated in IBM’s Master the Mainframe contest.  A junior at Lake Brantley High School, Nicholas successfully completed parts One and Two as a side project in his Java Programming class. Congrats to the Baio family! More information about the event is posted below: 

 

https://www.facebook.com/MasterTheMainframe

 The Master the Mainframe coding contest consists of three separate parts, each of which presents distinct challenges; the degree of coding difficulty increases as students progress to the next level. High school and college students log on remotely from their dorms, apartments, or computer labs to IBM System z mainframes, and are awarded prizes ranging from t-shirts for successfully completing Part One, to a laptop computer and a trip to IBM’s New York headquarters for winning Part Three.

  • Part One introduces students to the mainframe and gets them comfortable with remote secure access to an IBM mainframe, while performing simple tasks. Typically this portion of the challenge takes an hour or two to complete.
  • Part Two introduces contestants to advanced commands and system setup techniques; students usually spend approximately 30 to 40 hours on this portion of the match. Those who complete Parts One and Two receive hands-on experience in four operating systems (IBM’s mainframe z/OS; Linux on System z; z/Transactional Processing Facility, and z/Virtualization Machine).
  • Part Three is the most technically daunting coding challenge. Competitors utilize IBM’s Rational Developer for System zEnterprise coding tool to create complex, high-end CICS, IMS, DB2, and Batch applications to solve real-world business problems devised by IBM engineers.  The engineers typically take up to three months to review completed submissions; 2013’s top three finishers will be notified in March.

item.title: Lots of new faces, lots of new spaces...Please help us welcome our newest GKR'ers
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Victoria Boston, Research Analyst HC NYC x347

I graduated from Iona College with a degree in business management.  I previously worked at a start-up technology company called Singleplatform. On the weekends I enjoy traveling or spending time with family and friends. I look forward to meeting everyone in the next few weeks.

Stacey Sacket, Healthcare Recruiter NYC x346

I worked in Media Ad Sales for 14 years and decided I was ready for a change.  I graduated from Indiana University with a Business Degree and my current “hobby” is raising my 3 kids.  I am very excited to join the Green Key team and I look forward to meeting everyone. 

Lauren Marangiello, Office Support Recruiter NYC x380

Lauren Marangiello is a junior professional who is very excited to be starting her recruiting career with Green Key Resources. Originally born in Brooklyn, Lauren is a native New Yorker and graduate of Marymount Manhattan College. She previously worked in hospitality at P.J. Clarke’s as well as in Client Services at Physique 57. She is happy to be a new part of the Office Support Team as well as the rest of the Green Key family.

Mike Holzer, IT Recruiter Florida x247

I am a graduate of the University of Central Florida, earning my degree in English. I have enjoyed my (short) time with Green Key thus far, and have spent the bulk of my professional life working in Healthcare staffing and recruiting. In my spare time I enjoy playing football and basketball, and would enjoy watching them a lot more if the teams I cheered for were any good! I look forward to furthering my career aspirations with Green Key and learning a whole lot more about our organization!

Rory Valan, IT Recruiter Long Island x442

I graduated from Suffolk County Community College  in 2013 with an Associates Degree in Liberal Arts.  I started my career as in IT Recruiter and have about a year of experience in the IT industry.  I wanted to be in a fast paced growing team and I knew that the Long  Island GKR office would allow me to showcase my skillset.  I currently live in Patchogue, NY and enjoy playing basketball and spending time with my friends and family.  I am very excited to join the GKR team and I look forward to working with everyone.

Tara Potter, Pharma Temp North Carolina xTBD

I started my staffing career 8 years ago and spent the majority of it in the pharmaceutical industry focused solely on biometric contract recruiting. I had the pleasure of meeting some of the Green Key crew at conferences over the years and when Larry Goodman randomly called me one day to increase his outbound call numbers, I let him sell me on the company. I’m a West Virginia University graduate with a passion for swimming, running and traveling. I’m honored to be a part of the organization and I am excited to start this new chapter with all of you!

Jen Beers, IT Recruiter Rockville x444

I have worked in the recruiting industry for about 8 years. Prior to getting into this industry I was a middle school and high school science teacher. What I enjoy most about recruiting is interacting with candidates and matching them with opportunities that will enable them to reach their career goals. I enjoy being a mom to my 3 kids, playing tennis, running, and Zumba. I am excited to be a part of the Green Key team and look forward to the success that lies ahead.

Sarah A. Friedman, AF Recruiter Rockville x445

I am excited to join the Rockville, MD office.  I am joining Green Key with 10+ years of recruiting experience.  My husband and I moved to Maryland 10 years ago (we are native New Yorkers).  We have two AMAZING kids (Braxton, turning 8 years old on Saturday, and Shaina is 5 ½ years old).  We also have two crazy animals, a dog and cat.  I have my MBA degree in Accounting from Fordham University and am truly excited to be working here with a great group of people.   

Diana Hinojosa, Research Analyst NYC x443

I graduated from Hunter College this past summer with a major in Economics. After graduation I took some time off to do a theatre conservatory program and travel.  I previously worked in Creative Marketing and International Sales at Revlon. I became interested in recruiting after speaking with someone from the company, David Hannan. I am really excited to learn more about recruiting and meeting everyone.

item.title: Welcome the newest members of the Green Key Team!
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Bill Graddy, Pharma Recruiter Chicago x342

I graduated from Indiana University in Dec. 2013 with a degree in Psychology.  After graduation I returned back home to the northside of Indianapolis before moving to Chicago in the summer of 2014.  I previously worked at Jobspring Partners as a technical recruiter.  I heard about Green Key from Tyler Wildt and he told me about how great the Chicago office is.  I am excited to learn this new market and move my career forward here at Green Key.

Deni Passaretti, AF Recruiter Long Island x453

I graduated from San Diego State University with a BA in Neuropsychology, minor in Statistics. After living in California for 5 years, I decided to move back home to NY to be closer to family. I have worked as a recruiter in finance/accounting at Stephen James Associates, the accounting & finance subdivision of Aerotek. My interests include performance/dance hula hooping and running my small business, Hoopnotism. I make custom-made hula hoops for all ages, shapes, sizes, and experience levels. I am so excited to join the team and I look forward to growing with Green Key Resources as a whole. 

Jenna Roden, IT Recruiter Orlando x351

After graduating from Florida State University in 2013, I moved to DC and started working as a Recruiter at a small staffing firm.  When deciding to move back to Florida, I was put in contact with Joey and soon there after relocated to Orlando. I am looking forward to getting to know my team and starting a career with Green Key. Outside of the office I love being on the water and traveling as much as possible.

Samantha Black, Pharma Recruiter Orlando x352

I graduated in 2014 with a JD from Barry University School of Law and in 2011 with a degree in Psychology from Baruch College. While passionate about the law, I have not found the practice of law to be as  fulfilling as I had hoped. I am an avid traveler with a love of anything new and spontaneous! I am excited to be a part of the GKR team and looking forward to meeting everyone. 

Samantha Wierzbicki, Internal Recruiter NYC x133

I graduated from Princeton University in 2014 with a degree in English literature. The day after graduation, I flew to Nan, Thailand to complete a year-long service fellowship with Princeton in Asia. During that time, I taught conversational English to hundreds of elementary-aged Thai children. Moving to New York less than a week after returning to the US, I immediately started job hunting and found myself accepting an internal recruiting role at Green Key. I am so excited to start my career in recruiting and very ready to meet everyone in the office!

Brett Sereysky, Financial Services Recruiter NYC x177

I graduated from the University of Rochester in 2010. I started my career at The Royal Bank of Scotland in Stamford, CT and after three and a half years, left to work at Goldman. I was introduced to Green Key in March when I came in to meet with Jackie DeJohn to find a different job within the financial services arena. After our meeting, I was intrigued by Green Key’s approach to recruiting and knew it would provide the challenging and fast paced environment that I was looking for. I am so excited to be a part of this team and truly look forward to meeting everyone.     

Hope Gofton, Staff Accountant NYC x272

I graduated from the University of Central Florida with a B.S. in Accounting in 2014. During college I worked in accounting for Universal Studios (Orlando) and Novo Nordisk Inc, and upon moving to NYC I temped as a Staff Accountant for Citi Habitats. I am very excited to be working for Green Key and to learn everything I can. 

Aaron Lichtenstein, AF Recruiter NYC x154

I worked at Ernst & Young and Deloitte for the past 4 years. I got my Masters in Accounting from Fairleigh Dickinson University and did Real Estate tax practice at EY. I realized I was ready to become a recruiter when he recruited 10 people to Ernst & Young from different places. Besides recruiting, I also enjoy golf and fantasy football.

Bo Kim – Pharma Recruiter NYC x390

I graduated from University of Delaware in 2012 and have been working in the healthcare industry before joining GKR. I like to be pretty active whether it’s in the gym or playing in basketball leagues in NJ or NYC (If anybody plays on a team and has a roster spot let me know!). Random fact about me is I have lived all over the US from Hawaii, Los Angeles, Detroit, Philadelphia, Baltimore to finally Greater NYC area. I look forward to meeting everyone in the next few weeks.

item.title: A special shout out to Theresa Rhea's son winning a prestigious award gaining him college scholarships...view his art piece below!
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Ultimately this award opens college scholarship opportunities for him. Normally  this National award would have been listed on his college application as a way to weight his application for acceptance BUT the two main schools he wanted to include a few other back up schools already sent him his acceptance.  This award allows him to compete for the Claes Nobel Academic Scholarships and national Scholar Awards but there are many other scholarships available to him as well that are not available to others just because he is now apart of this group for winning this award.

 

Moving forward this piece of art will be shown over the course of 24 months through the country. 

 

His art will be on display in NY for about 3-4 months before it ships to FL for the beginning of the National tour. 

*** tour is: Art.Write.Now 2015 National Exhibition

 

There are two addresses listed for the initial display of the art work in NY:

 

Sheila C Johnson Design Center

Parson The New School for Design

66 Fifth Avenue at 13th Street

And

Pratt Manhattan Gallery

144 West 14th, 2nd Floor

 

This award will be personally given to him at a ceremony on June 11th at Carnegie Hall, NY

Thanks again for the interest.  I hope others find it interesting as well or at least inspiring for their kids, even in High School you can win big awards for things you do, accomplish.

item.title: Thank YOU for donating your used coats this past winter
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Dear Randi Bleichfeld,

All of us at New York Cares thank you for your support of the 26th Annual Coat Drive. Together, we extended the Coat Drive’s reach and provided much-needed warmth to over 75,000 New Yorkers in desperate need of protection against the harsh winter.

In just seven weeks, we collected and distributed more than 75,000 winter coats.  To accomplish that feat New York Cares relies heavily on the generosity of a very special group of corporate sponsors, individuals, and city agencies for their financial and in-kind support. Your participation in that group made a tremendous contribution to raising the profile of our effort and to achieving our goal to ensure New Yorkers stay warm during the winter. We are deeply grateful.

We encourage you to learn more about Coat Drive 2014’s success by reviewing our annual Coat Drive Report.  You can download it here.

Thank you again for your support of this critical New York City initiative.  We look forward to deepening our partnership with you for the 27th New York Cares Coat Drive.

 

Thank you,

Rebecca Moramarco, Manager, Corporate Service

New York Cares| THE WAY TO VOLUNTEER

65 Broadway, 19th Floor, New York NY 10006



[1]

item.title: Green Key has been hiring more talented people!!
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Please help us welcome the newest members of Green Key!!!!!! Read more about them below

NEW YORK CITY
Amanda Lopez, AF Recruiter NYC x432
I graduated from The University of Florida in 2010 with a BS in Accounting. I moved back to South Florida and began my professional career with Tyco International in Boca Raton working as a Property Tax Analyst for ADT Security Services and then shifted internally as a Staff Accountant for Simplex Grinnell. I moved to NYC a year and a half ago and began working shortly thereafter at EY in FSO Tax – Asset Management. My interests include anything that takes me outdoors and keeps me active. Very excited to be here at GKR and looking forward to meeting everyone.

Kelly Barnum, Research Analyst Temp NYC, x273
I recently graduated from the University of Pittsburgh with a B.S. in marketing and human resources management. I have been interested in recruiting for a while now and am so excited to be starting my career with Green Key. I am originally from Buffalo, NY and some of my interests include traveling, music, dance, and food. I am really looking forward to getting to know everyone!

Taryn Spiegel, Research Analyst Pharma NYC x681
I just graduated from the University of Maryland this past May, with a BS in Family Science. I was born and raised in Westchester, NY. I was recently introduced to Green Key in April by Alison Arditi. My interests include traveling, running, seeing movies and hanging out with friends. I could not be more excited to be part of the team here and really look forward to meeting everyone!

Charlotte Jackson, Research Analyst Temp NYC x682
I have an Undergraduate degree in Psychology and a Masters in Human Resource Management, both of which I completed in the UK. During my studies I worked full time in order to save money for travel. I have spent a minimum of a month each in Africa, South Africa, Nepal, Thailand, Continental Europe and many more. I have always wanted to live in NYC and after completing my MA I decided just to go for it. So far I’m loving it and feel very lucky to have secured this position so quickly. I’m looking forward to getting to know everyone here and really getting stuck into this fast paced environment.

Tom Preziose, Financial Services NYC x196
I come from a Finance background working at Credit Suisse and RBC Capital Markets. Recently I transitioned my career and started my first recruiting job here at Green Key Resources in the Financial Services team. I live in Hoboken New Jersey, I am a big Giants fan and like snowboarding during the winter.

Paulina Harris, Accounting Finance NYC x152
I have worked in staffing/recruiting for the past year in the accounting and finance industry. I started working at a small recruiting firm after studying at Binghamton University, and look forward to continuing my career at Green Key. My hobbies include snacking, traveling and exploring new places such as Australia, New Zealand and Israel. I am excited to learn more and progress at GKR.

Caitlin Costello, Research Analyst NYC x348
My name is Caitlin Costello and I just joined the Green Key team this past week. I graduated from the University of Delaware this past spring with a Bachelors of Arts in Political Science with a concentration in Global studies and a minor in history. I am currently working on two teams, legal under Dara and in Business Development under Randi. I am sitting by the second kitchen in the front by Dara, feel free to stop by when you can to say hi. Look forward to meeting everyone. I am very excited to have joined the firm.

LONG ISLAND
Tim Hartill, Temp Healthcare Long Island x460
I have worked in staffing and recruiting for over 9 months. I previously worked at The Execu-Search Group as a Staffing Manager in the Healthcare division. Prior to joining The Execu-Search Group, I worked for Teachers Federal Credit Union. I hold a Bachelor’s degree in Business Management from Cazenovia College where, I played soccer and my interests include sports and hanging out with friends. I enjoy the fast pace, challenging and exciting activity that comes with this job. I look forward to learn more as I progress with my career at GKR.

Naomi Noach, AF Recruiter Long Island x418
I graduated from SUNY Plattsburgh in 2008. I moved to Long Island from upstate New York four years ago. I have worked in office support temporary staffing for the past three years. In my free time I like to go camping and hiking. I am currently working on climbing all 46 peaks in the Adirondack Mountains. I am excited to join the Accounting and Finance team here in Long Island.

FLORIDA
Bobby Zvonchenko, Pharma Temp Florida x337
I graduated from the University of Florida in May of 2015. Green Key is my first real career move and I couldn’t be more excited about the opportunity! Sports has always been my main interest in life, I used to play football until I was forced into retirement at the young age of 17. I am thrilled to be apart of the Green Key Family!

Michelle Bonilla, Pharma Temp Florida x334
I graduated from UCF. I worked for Disney Vacation Club for about 2 years. I love to play Badminton and I like to win. I am excited to join Green Key and start the next chapter in my life.

Ashley Murphy, Pharma Temp Florida x336
I graduated from the University of Central Florida in 2012 with a B.S. in Marketing. After graduating college I began working as a Pharmaceutical Customer Service Associate at Publicis Touchpoint Solutions. I love to travel; at least once a year I try to go someplace that I’ve never been before. I am very excited about joining the GK team and I look forward to working with everyone!

Huy Luong, IT Florida x383
I graduated from the University of Central Florida with a B.A. in Legal Studies. I am in my last semester at Valencia College working towards a degree in Computer Information Technology. I was a paralegal for a few years before this job. I go to the gym 5 to 6 times a week as I love to keep an active and healthy lifestyle. I also enjoy visiting the beach and trying new food/restaurants during my free time.

NORTH CAROLINA
Beth Ward, Pharma North Carolina x613
I have been a recruiter in the pharmaceutical industry for five years. Throughout my career, I have focused heavily in biometrics on both contract and permanent positions. Until I was sold here on the Green Key culture by my mentor, Tara Potter, I previously supported Chiltern/Ockham Source. I am a North Carolina native, graduate of East Carolina, mother of two, with a passion for photography…. Go ECU Pirates! I’m honored to be a part of this team and look forward to the adventure ahead.

Lynnette Monroe, Pharma North Carolina x683
I have worked in the recruiting world for almost three years now. Prior to my recent employment with Green Key, I was a Recruiting Support Specialist for SRG Woolf Group and helped manage their GSK account. I was born and raised here in Raleigh, NC and graduated from Peace College in 2011. I am a little bit of a health nut, and love to play volleyball as well as weight train in my spare time. I am so, so excited to be a part of the Green Key team and look forward to meeting and working with all of you!

MARYLAND
Sofia Mouloua, Research Analyst Rockville x682
I graduated from the University of Maryland with a degree in Government and Politics. I grew up in the DC metro area. I enjoy yoga, traveling, and listening to music. I am excited to start my career in recruiting and I look forward to meeting everyone!

MASSACHUSETTS
Nicole Danis, IT Massachusetts X610
I graduated from the University of New Hampshire in 2013. I have since worked at Sprint for a year and a half and one of my customers introduced me to the recruiting firm Robert Half. One of my colleagues I had at Robert Half introduced me to Green Key. In my free time I enjoy going to Red Sox games, I had the privilege of attending the 2013 World Series game 6. I also enjoy the movies and traveling in my time off. I am very excited to be joining the Green Key team and look forward to what the future holds.

item.title: Welcome the newest members of the Green Key Team!
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
New York:

Daniel Schimel - Accounting/Finance, NYC x379

I have a bachelor’s degree in finance and an MBA in accounting from Rutgers University.  The bulk of my accounting work experience is from PWC in their banking & capital markets tax group, and most recently at Untracht Early in their high net worth tax group.  I worked for a couple of years at RSM McGladrey doing internal corporate recruiting and that’s where I first discovered Green Key, through a meeting with Jason Kien and Andrew Chayut.  I am very excited to join Green Key Resources and look forward to meeting everyone.

Jonathan Blumenthal - Financial Services, NYC x611

I graduated from Indiana University in May. I went abroad to Barcelona in the spring of 2014 and enjoy traveling. I am a huge sports fan and my favorite teams are the Raiders, Mets, Knicks, and Rangers. My favorite shows on TV right now are Ballers and Ray Donovan. I found out about Green Key through Jay Kien and was intrigued by the opportunity to start my career here. I can’t wait to meet and work with all of you.

Jason Chow - Financial Services, NYC x430

I graduated from Babson College in 2002 and worked at BlackRock Financial until 2013 and Stone Harbor until 2014.   I had a chance to help a friend find a job that she loved and realized I have a passion for this.  When I’m not working I’m an avid cook, and love a hard round of sparring in Thai kickboxing.  I’m very excited to join GreenKey and can’t wait to meet everyone.

Kara Rosenberg - Healthcare Perm/HC Temp, NYC x445

Hi everyone, my name is Kara. I graduated in May of 2014 from Penn State University. I thoroughly enjoyed my time there where I studied Public Relations, joined a sorority and spent a semester abroad in Seville, Spain. Shortly after I graduated I secured an HR/recruiting position with a marketing firm in Manhattan. With this position, I learned that I loved recruiting and having the ability to meet and speak with new people every day. In my down time, I love to cook, play with my dogs and travel. I look forward to furthering my career with Green Key Resources and getting the chance to work with so many great people!  

 

Amanda Casey - Office Support, NYC x288

I graduated from Indiana University in 2014 with a Bachelor’s in Psychology and a minor in Business Management. During my time at Indiana University, I was on the dance team and participated in a Semester at Sea program that allowed me to travel throughout the Mediterranean. Upon graduation, I began my career as a Business Analyst with Single Platform (a part of Constant Contact) and then transitioned into recruitment. I worked as an Associate Consultant at Michael Page where I sat on the Advisory team and specialized in the recruitment of strategy and technology professionals in Management Consulting. I am very excited to join the team at GKR and am looking forward to meeting everyone over the next couple of weeks. 

Justin Stratton - Office Support, NYC x441

I am originally from the land of corn & hogs also known as Iowa. After escaping the homeland, I spent several years at Digitas here in NYC supporting executives in Creative and Technology. I also co-founded Mark Fisher Fitness as the “Marketing & Membership Pimp” (aka head of sales and marketing/social media) Most recently, I have been working as a Career Coach and host The Awesomeness Show podcast. I came to Green Key thanks to my good friend, Regina Gatti. I love traveling, theater and a good cocktail.

Long Island:

Alicia Irizarry -  OS Temp Long Island x423

I graduated from Loyola University Maryland with a B.A. in Psychology this past May. I worked as an office assistant for the HR Department and became interested in the process of recruiting. Having worked in the customer service industry for the last several years, I am excited by a fast-paced work environment and the opportunity to interact with people from all walks of life. I look forward to learning and growing in this role and to meeting everyone at GKR!

Orlando:

Rachel Saager - Pharma Temp Orlando x333

I graduated from University of Central Florida in 2010 and from Long Island, New York. I decided those New York winters were too cold so I moved back down here in 2013. I was previously working for a home health care company and was responsible for their sales/marketing in Orange, Osceola, and Seminole County. While interviewing for Green Key Resources I had realized a high school friend of mine used to work in the New York branch. I was interested by the opportunity and couldn’t wait to start. I am very excited to join the team and look forward to my developing career at Green Key!

Rockville, MD:

Simran Othee - Accounting/Finance, Rockville x552

I recently just graduated with my MBA this past December from Albany, New York. After graduation, I worked as an IT recruiter for a company called Aerotek in Fairfax, Virginia, which opened my eyes to the staffing and recruiting industry. Some of my interests include working out, watching/playing sports and traveling whenever I get a chance. I'm very excited about working and getting my career started at Green Key Resources and look forward to meeting everyone!

Joe Giordano - Accounting/Finance, Rockville x529

I recently graduated from the University of Florida. While there I worked at the Stephen C. O’Connell Center, a 12,000 seat multipurpose venue that hosts all indoor sports for the Florida Gators as well as concerts and other large events. I’m a huge sports fan and especially enjoy college football and basketball, as well as the NHL. I was introduced to Green Key by Bobby Zvonchenko, who I worked with at the O’Connell Center. I’m very excited to get started and I’m looking forward to meeting you all!

Lauren Mason - Office Support Temp Rockville x553

I graduated from the University of Maryland in 2014. Since graduating, I have worked in the financial industry and left to pursue a career in recruiting at Green Key. I love traveling and being outside; one of my most exciting vacations was to Costa Rica with friends to explore the rainforest. I’m excited about the future and getting to know everyone! 

North Carolina:

Jennifer Wheeler - Pharma Temp, North Carolina x439

I graduated from East Carolina University with a BSBA in Business Marketing. After graduation, I was introduced into the staffing world running a “full desk” split between a recruiter and account manager in the IT industry. I transitioned into the pharmaceutical realm shortly after and have been a clinical recruiter for the past 2 years. I was referred over here via my old colleague and friend Lynnette, who is currently with me here in Chicago to see the office and meet the team. Everyone here is great and I’m so excited for what’s to come here at Green Key Resources!! 

Catherine Baker -  Pharma Perm, North Carolina x286

I have been a recruiter for over 7 years in the healthcare and pharmaceutical industry. I previously worked at Chiltern as a Senior Corporate Recruiter. I graduated from North Carolina State University, Go Wolfpack!! I live in Raleigh and love traveling and spending time with my husband and our St. Bernard. I am so excited to join Green Key and look forward to getting to know everyone.

item.title: Introducing the Green Key Creative Team in NYC
item.dc:creator: Marina-White
item.content:encoded:
Located in New York City, one of fashion’s capital cities, Green Key Creative, specializes in staffing marketing and creative talent within fashion, beauty, and lifestyle’s top retailers, wholesalers, eCommerce, and advertising agencies.

Freelance and full time roles we staff:

digital design and production, print and packaging, project management, copywriting and proofreading, photography and retouching, web development, public relations, advertising, traditional and digital marketing, social media, and eCommerce marketing and merchandising.  

The Creative team will be spearheaded by Margaret Lambert, who will be building the team with Meredith Robinson. Both Margaret and Meredith have spent their careers in fashion and recruiting prior to joining Green Key.  Please help me welcome them to our firm. They are sitting in the back of the NYC bullpen, by my office. Please stop by and introduce yourself if you haven’t met them already, or give them a call if you aren’t in NYC. Read more about them below:

Margaret Lambert – Creative, Sales x198

I attended college at FIT, and I started my career working in the fashion industry as a wholesale sales rep. Shortly after, I began my career in recruiting at Randstad in a business development role. I was promoted to a Staffing Manager and managed the Estee Lauder Companies account. I moved on to work at Career Group Inc., where I spearheaded the creation of a marketing and creative division in fashion and beauty, fourthFLOOR creative. I’m very excited to join Green Key’s team, and I’m looking forward to working with you all.

Meredith Robinson – Creative, Recruiting x130

I am originally from Tennessee, and initially came to New York to study fashion design at Pratt. After receiving my MBA in entrepreneurship from LIM College, I worked in fashion wholesale at Yves Saint Laurent. I began recruiting a year ago at fourthFLOOR Creative, focusing on creative marketing roles within fashion and beauty. In my free time, I enjoy drawing, traveling, and spending time with my dog. I’m very excited to join the Green Key team!

item.title: Welcome to our 3 newest team members!

item.content:encoded:
Gina Scott - Senior Recruiter, Maryland x286

I’m a former CFO with experience in diverse industries – healthcare, professional services, nonprofit, and retail.   I have a passion for travel, especially cruises.   My proudest achievement is my daughter, Britni, who is my greatest cheerleader!   I began my staffing and recruiting career with the Management Resources Division of Robert Half International, where I managed their Salaried Professional Services practice.  After 5 years with Robert Half, I worked with a staffing firm in the Rockville area, where I met my staffing “family” – Judy, Amy and Karri. I’m looking forward to working with everyone at Green Key; and am very excited to be reunited with the great team in Rockville…it feels like I’m returning home!

Matthew Schirano - Technical Recruiter, Long Island x419

I graduated from SUNY Cortland in 2012 with a degree in Finance. I started my career as a technical recruiter with TEKsystems and was there for almost a year. I knew that I wanted to be in a fast paced, challenging competitive environment and I knew that GKR could provide me with that. I currently live in St. James, NY and enjoy playing Baseball and Golf on my spare time.  I am very excited to join the GKR team and I look forward to working with everyone!

Erika Reichelscheimer - Internal Research/Marketing, New York - x423

I graduated from the University at Albany in 2012. After graduation, I worked for a nonprofit organization which registers voters at live music events, concerts and festivals. It was an amazing experience! My transition into the for profit world played into my love for the great outdoors; working for a park guide publishing company. I am very excited to jump into the fast paced world of recruiting and become an integral part of the Green Key team!

item.title: Tinder for Recruiters? Check out TheLadders' new FREE recruiting app!
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Turn unproductive downtime into valuable searching time with TheLadders' new and improved recruiting app. The new version makes it easier then ever to find qualified job seekers, and for job seekers to find you, while on the go! 

Just post a job, input the types of professionals you’re looking for and you'll get a feed of qualified candidates in the palm of your hand. You can swipe right to save a profile or left to pass on it. Accidentally discard the perfect candidate? Not a problem! You can undo your dismissal within seconds or access a portfolio of every candidate you've ever viewed on the app by logging into the web version of the site.

Another major appeal is that the app is free for both job seekers and recruiters. Plus, it makes instantly contacting the top applicants via phone, email or text super simple. 

For a more in depth look at all of the features click here or download it today and give it a try!

item.title: Welcome to our 4 new Green Key team members in 3 different offices!
item.dc:creator: randib@greenkeyllc.com
item.content:encoded:
Michelle Mendez - Sr. Recruiter, Temp OS Chicagoland Area, x424

Before joining GreenKey – I worked for a family owned staffing firm for 8 years called The Plus Group and in Dec 2012 they purchased 2 other staffing firms.  With the purchases they changed our name to Banner Personnel in the Chicagoland area. I started as a Staffing Recruiter and then moved up to Senior Recruiter.  Prior to that I was a Team Leader for XO Communication in the Project Management and Provisioning groups.  I’m excited about this opportunity to launch a New Division and to work along side Alan.  We are lucky to have great resources with having the Pharma group across the hall.  Look forward to working with the whole team and getting to know everyone!

Alan Maeder – Sales Manager, Temp OS Chicagoland Area, Chicago, x425

Alan has worked in the staffing and recruiting industry for over 16 years.  He previously worked at Banner Personnel for 14 years with his last position as a Selling Branch Manager.  While at Banner Personnel, Alan focused in the Office Services vertical selling short term temporary to direct hire staffing solutions.  He holds a Bachelor’s Degree in History from Truman State University, a liberal arts and sciences university located in Missouri.  His interests include spending time with his family and running.  He is very excited to join the Green Key Resources team and looks forward to working with and meeting everyone.

Katelyn York – Associate Recruiter, Healthcare NYC, x122

I graduated from Dickinson College in 2010 with a BA in English. I started my career at Penguin Group publishing in the Special Sales department as an assistant. After working in publishing for a few years, I made the move to consumer goods working in national and gift sales department at BUILT NY- a company specializing in products made from neoprene. I recently decided to make a career change into recruiting and found GKR. I enjoy traveling to both sunny and snowy places in my spare time. I am extremely excited to join the GKR team and I look forward to meeting everyone.

Kristina Andrews – Technical Recruiter, Orlando, x382

I have 14 years of recruiting and staffing experience starting as an internal corporate recruiter with a Voice/Data implementation partner, moving into IT Staffing in 2005 after a short time working in Title/Escrow Recruiting and Account Management. I’m originally from Orange County, CA but moved to Boca Raton, FL in 2005 and landed in Orlando back in 2008. I’m looking forward to working with everyone and being an integral part of growing Green Key’s IT Placement Division.
